resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>Indiana University Center for the Study of History and Memory</corpname>
                     <address>
                        <addressline>Indiana University</addressline>
                        <addressline>400 North Sunrise Drive</addressline>
                        <addressline>Weatherly Hall North, Room 122</addressline>
                        <addressline>Bloomington, IN 47405</addressline>
                        <addressline>Phone: 812/855-2856</addressline>
                        <addressline>Fax: 812/855-0002</addressline>
                        <addressline>E-mail: ohrc@indiana.edu</addressline>
                     </address>
                     <extref>http://www.indiana.edu/~cshm</extref>
                  </repository>
                  <origination>
                     <corpname>Indiana University Center for the
                    Study of History and Memory</corpname>
                  </origination>
                  <unittitle>Legal Profession in Indiana</unittitle>
                  <unitdate>1976-1980</unitdate>
                  <unitid>ohrc113</unitid>
                  <physdesc>
                     <extent>6 interview</extent>. <extent>Audiotapes, transcripts, and collateral
                    materials</extent>. </physdesc>
                  <physloc>Interviews are housed in Weatherly Hall North, Room
                122. Copies are also housed at the Indiana University Archives in Herman B Wells
                Library E460. For other locations housing the interviews from this project, please
                contact the Center for the Study of History and Memory office.</physloc>
                  <langmaterial>Materials are in <language>English</language>.</langmaterial>
                  <abstract> This project contains interviews with attorneys in Indiana. Among
                the topics discussed are the Indiana Judiciary System, the Indiana General
                Assembly, the United States Legislature, the United States Supreme Court, the
                Monroe County judiciary system and Monroe County politics. All interviewees
                reflect upon the public's perception of the legal profession and how is has
                changed over the years.</abstract>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Legal Profession in Indiana 1976-1980
resource.abstract: This project contains interviews with attorneys in Indiana. Among                the topics discussed are the Indiana Judiciary System, the Indiana General                Assembly, the United States Legislature, the United States Supreme Court, the                Monroe County judiciary system and Monroe County politics. All interviewees                reflect upon the public's perception of the legal profession and how is has                changed over the years.
resource.extent: 6 interview; Audiotapes, transcripts, and collateral                    materials

                  <abstract>Autobiographical sketch of Osborn, written in 1979, which covers his undergraduate and graduate education at, respectively, DePauw University, Northwestern University, and the California Institute of Technology; his work at the Geophysical Defense Research Committee of the Office of Scientific Research and Development, Eastman Kodak, and finally as professor of geochemistry at Pennsylvania State University. File also includes a curriculum vitae and a list of publications. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Unknown</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

File also includes a curriculum vitae and a list of publications.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:535713135</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-HUV</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Hansbrow, Thomas H.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers of Thomas H. Hansbrow, 1852-1972 (bulk 1852-1881).</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection consists of one manuscript which has been separated into 4 folders and 19 pieces of correspondence arranged by date and 30 pieces of ephemera arranged by subject. The manuscript is the memoir of Thomas H. Hansbrow's brother-in-law, Samuel A. Randel, and there are sections which relate to Hansbrow's marriage and travel to California in 1849. Mostly, the manuscript recounts the author's family history and his personal life. There are many descriptions of his boyhood in Illinois in the 1840s and 1850s. Most of the correspondence is to Thomas H. Hansbrow regarding the various pumps he designed for mining, steamers, agriculture and railroads. There are a few letters regarding family and friends. The ephemera consists of 30 items. It contains diagrams and graphs of the pumps Hansbrow designed and sold, his wife's will, materials from Hansbrow's involvement in the World's Fair and newspaper articles regarding Hansbrow. Subjects in the collection include: California State Agricultural Society; DePauw University; Farm life in Illinois; inventors of California; history of Macoupin County, Ill.; Design and construction of Pumping machinery; the United States Civil War; and Voyages to the Pacific coast. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Huntington Library, Art Collections & Botanical Gardens</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Papers of Thomas H. Hansbrow, 1852-1972 (bulk 1852-1881).
resource.abstract: The collection consists of one manuscript which has been separated into 4 folders and 19 pieces of correspondence arranged by date and 30 pieces of ephemera arranged by subject. The manuscript is the memoir of Thomas H. Hansbrow's brother-in-law, Samuel A. Randel, and there are sections which relate to Hansbrow's marriage and travel to California in 1849. Mostly, the manuscript recounts the author's family history and his personal life. There are many descriptions of his boyhood in Illinois in the 1840s and 1850s. Most of the correspondence is to Thomas H. Hansbrow regarding the various pumps he designed for mining, steamers, agriculture and railroads. There are a few letters regarding family and friends. The ephemera consists of 30 items. It contains diagrams and graphs of the pumps Hansbrow designed and sold, his wife's will, materials from Hansbrow's involvement in the World's Fair and newspaper articles regarding Hansbrow. Subjects in the collection include: California State Agricultural Society; DePauw University; Farm life in Illinois; inventors of California; history of Macoupin County, Ill.; Design and construction of Pumping machinery; the United States Civil War; and Voyages to the Pacific coast.
resource.displayEntry: Hansbrow, Thomas H. Papers of Thomas H. Hansbrow, 1852-1972 (bulk 1852-1881).

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:247150109</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-ILM</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Bartholomew, Orion A.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>[Papers], 1854-1888.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection includes letters written by Orion Bartholomew to his family while attending Indiana Asbury University (1856-1861) and while serving in the Union Army during the Civil War with the 15th Regiment, United States Colored Troops. Also included are programs from Indiana Asbury University and Danville Academy, and a printed speech of John Coburn (1868). Also included are letters written by Levi Bartholomew to his family while in service with the 11th Regiment, Indiana Volunteers, during the Civil War. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Lincoln Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: [Papers], 1854-1888.
resource.abstract: The collection includes letters written by Orion Bartholomew to his family while attending Indiana Asbury University (1856-1861) and while serving in the Union Army during the Civil War with the 15th Regiment, United States Colored Troops. Also included are programs from Indiana Asbury University and Danville Academy, and a printed speech of John Coburn (1868). Also included are letters written by Levi Bartholomew to his family while in service with the 11th Regiment, Indiana Volunteers, during the Civil War.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>

                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Family materials, 1830-1949.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection contains papers, photographs, and photo albums of Hallie Yeoman-Cooley and her family. Among the photographs is a carte de visite from the Civil War of Isaac P. Foland of the 34th Indiana Infantry Regiment. The manuscript material contains various letters, legal papers, and a family genealogy. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Indiana Historical Society Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Family materials, 1830-1949.
resource.abstract: The collection contains papers, photographs, and photo albums of Hallie Yeoman-Cooley and her family. Among the photographs is a carte de visite from the Civil War of Isaac P. Foland of the 34th Indiana Infantry Regiment. The manuscript material contains various letters, legal papers, and a family genealogy.
resource.extent: Manuscript Materials: 1 document case, 1 oversize folder.Visual Materials: 1 box of photographs, 1 box of OVA size photographs, 2 photo albums, 1 panoramic photograph.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:650308728</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-XHS</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Newspaper graphics collection, 1854-1910.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>This collection consists of illustrations from thirteen different news publications. The images are of Indiana citizens, events, political cartoons, advertisements, people, and places in the state of Indiana. Some full articles accompany the illustrations. The majority of pages represented are from Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper and Harper's Weekly. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Indiana Historical Society Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Newspaper graphics collection, 1854-1910.
resource.abstract: This collection consists of illustrations from thirteen different news publications. The images are of Indiana citizens, events, political cartoons, advertisements, people, and places in the state of Indiana. Some full articles accompany the illustrations. The majority of pages represented are from Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper and Harper's Weekly.
resource.extent: 1 OVA graphics box, 2 OVB graphics boxes, 1 OVC graphics box.

resource.title: Indiana History mss., 1725-1973
resource.abstract: Consists of individual items acquired separately either as a gift, purchase, transfer, or removal from a variety of sources, relating to Indiana. Includes correspondence, diaries, minutes, financial records, memoirs, articles about specific areas of the state, and legal documents. Additions continue to be made.

address.text: Indiana University 1200 E. Seventh St. Bloomington, IN 47405-5500 Phone: 812-855-2452 Fax: 812-855-3143 Email: liblilly@indiana.edu

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:39257253</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-XHS</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Warren, Stanley, 1932-</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Collection, 1943-1995 (bulk 1973-1979)</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Personal and professional papers of Stanley Warren, including correspondence, editorials and newsclippings, and published and unpublished manuscripts.  Correspondence includes letters as advocate for several causes.  Newspaper articles are both by and about Warren.  Manuscripts and publications deal with African-American students at DePauw University and in Indianapolis Public Schools; African-Americans on postage stamps; and numerous other topics concerning African-American education and history. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Indiana Historical Society Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Collection, 1943-1995 (bulk 1973-1979)
resource.abstract: Personal and professional papers of Stanley Warren, including correspondence, editorials and newsclippings, and published and unpublished manuscripts.  Correspondence includes letters as advocate for several causes.  Newspaper articles are both by and about Warren.  Manuscripts and publications deal with African-American students at DePauw University and in Indianapolis Public Schools; African-Americans on postage stamps; and numerous other topics concerning African-American education and history.

                  <langmaterial>Materials are in <language>English</language>
                  </langmaterial>
                  <abstract>This collection of interviews presents the life histories and impressions of a
                variety of residents from or near Paoli, Indiana. The interviewees range in age from
                early twenties to senior citizens and represent diverse professions, educational
                levels, and interests. This collection highlights some of the major changes in
                Orange County over the twentieth century and provides insight into the rich
                community life experienced by its residents.</abstract>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: History: Paoli, Indiana 1987-1989
resource.abstract: This collection of interviews presents the life histories and impressions of a                variety of residents from or near Paoli, Indiana. The interviewees range in age from                early twenties to senior citizens and represent diverse professions, educational                levels, and interests. This collection highlights some of the major changes in                Orange County over the twentieth century and provides insight into the rich                community life experienced by its residents.
resource.extent: 40 interviews; Audiotapes, transcripts, and collateral                    materials

resource.title: Whiting, Indiana: Generational Memory 1991-1993
resource.abstract: This collection of interviews primarily delves into the Republican                view of Indiana politics from the nineteen twenties to the early nineteen                sixties. Major emphasis is placed on both state and national elections and                conventions from 1940-1948. The project contains discussions of political                campaigns (including finances), the patronage system, and legislation battles.                The interviews also reflect on William Jenner by describing his character,                beliefs, and influence on Republican politics in Indiana.
resource.extent: 88 interviews; Audiotapes, transcripts, and collateral                    materials

                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:79449051</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:DLC</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Simpson, Matthew, 1811-1884.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers of Matthew Simpson, 1829-1929 (bulk 1833-1884).</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Family and general correspondence, diaries, journals, notebooks, notes, scrapbooks, copies of speeches, sermons, and writings, and miscellaneous printed material, chiefly 1833-1884, relating to Simpson's early life in Ohio and Pennsylvania, his presidency of Indiana Asbury (now De Pauw) University, his editorship of the Western Christian Advocate in Cincinnati, his service as a Methodist Episcopal bishop, with residences in Pittsburgh, Pa., Evanston, Ill., and Philadelphia, Pa., and his travels in Europe.  Includes information on the slavery question and on the church's struggles to expand during the 19th century.  Correspondents include Bishop Edward R. Ames, U.S. Postmaster General Montgomery Blair, U.S. Secretary of the Interior James Harlan, Bishop Edmund Janes, and Bishop Thomas A. Morris. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Unknown</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

Includes information on the slavery question and on the church's struggles to expand during the 19th century.  Correspondents include Bishop Edward R. resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>Indiana University Center for the Study of History and Memory</corpname>
                     <address>
                        <addressline>Indiana University</addressline>
                        <addressline>400 North Sunrise Drive</addressline>
                        <addressline>Weatherly Hall North, Room 122</addressline>
                        <addressline>Bloomington, IN 47405</addressline>
                        <addressline>Phone: 812/855-2856</addressline>
                        <addressline>Fax: 812/855-0002</addressline>
                        <addressline>E-mail: ohrc@indiana.edu</addressline>
                     </address>
                     <extref>http://www.indiana.edu/~cshm</extref>
                  </repository>
                  <origination>
                     <corpname>Indiana University Center for the
                    Study of History and Memory</corpname>
                  </origination>
                  <unittitle>Indiana Medicine</unittitle>
                  <unitdate>1993</unitdate>
                  <unitid>ohrc063</unitid>
                  <physdesc>
                     <extent>59 interviews</extent>. <extent>Audiotapes, transcripts, and collateral
                    materials</extent>. </physdesc>
                  <physloc>Interviews are housed in Weatherly Hall North, Room
                122. Copies are also housed at the Indiana University Archives in Herman B Wells
                Library E460. For other locations housing the interviews from this project, please
                contact the Center for the Study of History and Memory office.</physloc>
                  <langmaterial>Materials are in <language>English</language>
                  </langmaterial>
                  <abstract>This project is comprised of 59 interviews with doctors who have
                practiced medicine in the state of Indiana from approximately the nineteen
                thirties until the nineteen seventies, eighties, and nineties. The doctors
                share personal anecdotes about their medical practices in both rural and urban
                areas, their perspectives on the many changes medicine has undergone in the
                twentieth century, and the greatest satisfaction they received from their
                profession. Many interviews include physicians' experiences during World War
                II, African-American physicians' experiences under segregation, and how each
                individual adjusted to a profession that became increasingly specialized over
                the years.</abstract>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Indiana Medicine 1993
resource.abstract: This project is comprised of 59 interviews with doctors who have                practiced medicine in the state of Indiana from approximately the nineteen                thirties until the nineteen seventies, eighties, and nineties. The doctors                share personal anecdotes about their medical practices in both rural and urban                areas, their perspectives on the many changes medicine has undergone in the                twentieth century, and the greatest satisfaction they received from their                profession. Many interviews include physicians' experiences during World War                II, African-American physicians' experiences under segregation, and how each                individual adjusted to a profession that became increasingly specialized over                the years.
resource.extent: 59 interviews; Audiotapes, transcripts, and collateral                    materials

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:744952454</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Barstow, Stephen L.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Stephen L. Barstow Architectural records, 1953, 1988.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Architectural records, 1953, 1988, mostly undated, include a wide variety of formats and types of architectural records, among them records of various buildings of Midland, Michigan, including the Church of the Nazarene, and other nearby buildings including: West Midland Community Center, Northwood Institute, Crown Petroleum, Inc., gas station, Midland County Santa Claus Workshop, West Midland County Parks, and parts of Midland Hospital. Also included are architectural records for Interlochen Music Camp, Kent Intermediate Schools, Bay Refining Company Station, Central Pumping Station, DePauw University Performing Arts Center, Kalamazoo Nature Center, the Leonard Refineries, Inc. service station and sign, Wayne State University Theater, Young Subdivision, Roscommon Congregational Church, Temple Beth-El, Spring Valley (N.Y.), and lamps and decks.  Note: A number of the drawings in the collection are copyrighted by Alden B. Dow.  "Copyright of all Aden B. Dow materials is held by the Alden B. and Vada B. Dow Creativity Foundation. Patrons wishing to reproduce the material for purposes other than scholarship purposes must contact the Foundation. Copyright of all Aden B. Dow materials is held by the Alden B. and Vada B. Dow Creativity Foundation. Patrons wishing to reproduce the material for purposes other than scholarship purposes must contact the Foundation."   Note: The number of patrons using the collection will be reported monthly to Alden Dow Archives as per an agreement with the Clarke Historical Library, June 2011. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

Also included are architectural records for Interlochen Music Camp, Kent Intermediate Schools, Bay Refining Company Station, Central Pumping Station, DePauw University Performing Arts Center, Kalamazoo Nature Center, the Leonard Refineries, Inc. service station and sign, Wayne State University Theater, Young Subdivision, Roscommon Congregational Church, Temple Beth-El, Spring Valley (N.Y.), and lamps and decks. resource.title: History of Indiana University, 1968-1981
resource.abstract: This project is a compilation of interviews of subjects with strong ties to and memories of Indiana University, primarily at the Bloomington campus. The interviewees include former students, faculty, and staff, among others. The information contained in the interviews generally spans a little more than the first half of the twentieth century and often deals with the administrations under presidents William Lowe Bryan and Herman B Wells. The project is a survey of Indiana University's history as a whole including information about various academic departments, athletics, student organizations, campus growth, university development, living conditions, segregation and the treatment of African-Americans, the administration, and the importance of jazz at Indiana University. In addition, the impact of specific events, such as the Great Depression, World War I, World War II, the Vietnam War, and water shortages, is detailed in many of the interviews in this project.
resource.extent: 90 interviews; Audiotapes, transcripts, and collateral                    materials
